intro: Sida jatrophoides, commonly known as sandmat, is an annual herbaceous plant native to the southern United States and parts of Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its hairy stems and lobed leaves. The plant produces small, pale yellow flowers that bloom in clusters, followed by capsule fruits containing numerous seeds. Sida jatrophoides is adapted to sandy and disturbed soils, making it a common weed in agricultural and coastal areas. Its botanical features reflect its role as a resilient, sun-loving plant in diverse environments.
